document.text: Two youths who escaped Sun day afternoon from Appomattox County Jail under the pretext of washing the jail windows were  taken into custody early Mon- day, Sheriff L. L. Stanley re- j ported. j The boys, age 18 and 15, from Lynchburg Training School and Hospital, had recently been con !victed of breaking and entering I and each sentenced to five years the sheriff said. A woman employed as a baby sitter for Jailer H. A. White, who lives with his family at the jail, was working Sunday dur ing the absence of the jailer and his wife. Sheriff Stanley said the youths told the woman they were sup posed to wash windows but had nothing to do it with. When the woman brought cleaning items, the boys dashed by her and es caped, Stanley said. The two escapees were picked up early Monday on a second ary road. They had traveled only about three miles from jail.

document.text: Five Appomattox county white men have been charged in con nection with the throwing of an incendiary device into the home of Edward Thomas Johnson, as sistant principal of Carver Price High School. Sheriff L. L. Stanley said the incident occurred at Johnsons home about 230 a.m. Sunday. Johnsons wife was in the bath room when the incendiary came through the window, but she was not injured, said the sheriff, who reported that the screen had been cut. He said no clear-cut explana tion had emerged from his in vestigations, but he said the al leged participants are believed to have been drinking late Sat urday and early Sunday. Charged with a felony, malic ious destruction by using an ex plosive device or substance were Emory Woods, 26, and James Wirt Doss. 25, both of Ap pomattox. Three men charged with- aiding and Abetting in the Incident were Ronald Guill, 23 warren Eugene Guill, 26, and James Percy Ayers, 18, all of Appomattox. document.text: F. L. Murphy, Chairman of the Board of Supervisors for the past 13 years announced Friday that he will not seek re - election. The other two supervisors, O. W. Martin, Jr. and Richard Webb have stated that they will seek office in the primary this year. I am not going to run due to age and health, Mr. Murphy said. Please thank the people for their support. Chairman Murphy has served continuously as chairman of the three - man board since his first election to office. He serves the Southslde District O. W. Martin, Jr., the Stonewall District and Richard M. Webb, the Clover Hill District. Cole Announces John C. Cole, Dairyman, and resident of the Souttiside District, announced Tuesday that he will file petitions in April and plans to run for the Supervisors posi tion. Filing Date Filing date for office seekers to county posts is April 10. Each candidate for a place on the Democratic primary ballot on July 9, must pay a filing fee to the county Democratic Commit tee and must submit a petition or petitions bearing at least 50 names of qualified voters. Oher Offices Open Every county office Is up be fore the voters except the Clerk of Court who is elected for an eight year term. The present of fice holders, in addition to the supervisors, are Sheriff Walter Conner, Commissioner of Reve nue John Curtis Caldwell, Com monwealth Atorney George Ab- bitt, and County Treasurer Gar land plunkett have indicated that they will run again.  Possible Opposition jjphere are,, strong indications xogt. Ir. h i Stanley -He p Stete Police, may file in April to . run against Sheriff Conner. Sgt. Stanley soon due for retire ment from the State Police force, admitted his interest in the upcoming elections, but stat ed that his present duties as law enforcement officer prevent him from making any announcement at this time. Julian Wingfield, county chair man of the Republican party, stated Saturday that he has no announcement to make immedi ately. He indicated that a county meeting of Republicans would take place in the near future.

document.text: estate, escaped In his speed boat end here he washere, under this very roof I A robberthat was what he was I A robber bandit, such as one saw in the movies 1 That explained why he was so well- dressed, so handsome, had such fas cinating manners. He was e gentle man burglar. All up-to-date villains In these days were gentlemen. Not that ahe had ever encountered a villain In the fleBh. Still, she had read romances about them and waa there not one In every moving-picture? They were not diffi cult to recognise. It waa exhilaratingwonderful I A thief in the room overhead I Think of it! The very thief for whom all the police In the countryside were search ing ! He was no small, ehesp type of criminal. He did things on a big scale big that radio announcements had been broadcast about him and no doubt at this Instant detectives and crime Inspectors were chasing up and down the highways dashing through eltles and keeping telephone wires hot In wild search for the gentlemen asleep upstairs I Why, that very morning had not EH- aha Winslow, the Wilton sheriff, who had frankly admitted he yearned for excitement, helped undress the wretch and put him comfortably to bed? The humor of the situation almost over came her. It seemed as If she must have some one to share the Joke. But no one ahould. Not Nobody should be the wiser because of her. The poor, hunt ed fellow should have his chance. It was a little venturesome and risky, she admitted, to obstruct Justice and should she be found out she would, without doubt, be clapped Into Jail. Still she resolved to take a chance. After all, who could prove ahe had known Stanley Heath to be what he was? Nobody. She would not even let him suspect lt The Important thing was to await an opportunity and soonbefore he was able to be aboutreturn the hand kerchief she held In her hand to Its place beneath the brick. Then all would be well. This should not be dif ficult It would be quite easy to get Marcia to take up Mr. Heaths supper. In the meantime, the situation was Intensely amusing. Its danger ap pealed to her. She had always en joyed hair-breadth escapades. Any thing but dullness. That had been the trouble with Alton Citylt had been dulldeadly dulL But Wilton waa not dull. In spite of the fact that only this morning Elisha Winslow had complained the town was In need of a stirring up, It seethed with electricity. If she chose, she could hurl a bomb-shell Into Its midst this very minute. But she did not choose. Instead she Intended to play her own quiet game and keep what she knew to herself. She wondered why. Per haps she was falling in love with this adventures. Yes, that must be l t She was In love with himIn love with 1 bandit 1 Sylvias Imagination had traveled so swiftly and so far that lt came to earth with a crash when Marcia opened the door. It was not alone the buffeting of the salt breeze nor the exhilaration of walking against lt that had trans formed her Into something radiantly lovely. From within glowed a strange Are that made her another creature altogether. WhywhyMarcia! breathed Syl via, bewildered. Ive had such a glorious walk, dear! cried Marcia. The fog has lifted and the sky Is s sheet of amethyst and gold. Did the men get the boat off? Yes. She Is floating tranquilly os dove. What Is her name?  My Unknown Lady. Mercy on us 1 That ought to satisfy even Elisha. It did, said Marcia.
